instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2610: What is 820-2610? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> resistor issue
threads.message: Hello, for a project I decided to take on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>. It started as not turning on and having like .08V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. after tracing from DC in I found that <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> was burned up. I replaced it with a similar resistor and the board power up and showed a flashing ? folder. Well I left it on for about 10 min and I hear a 'pop' sound. I looked at <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> and it blew in half again. it got so hot the solder actually melted and the two halves of the resistor were standing on end. Before I dive headfirst into this sure to be rabbit hole, I wanted to ask the hive mind if there is a specific culprit for why the resistor blew in such a spectacular fashion. I also wanted to note that I am using an original MS1.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2610</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> resistor issue
threads.message:
Which was the exact ohm value of the replacement resistor?

Post diode mode to ground and exact voltage at <CAPACITOR>C6999</CAPACITOR>.
Be sure no corrosion present at <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, <CAPACITOR>C6994</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R6995</RESISTOR>/96.

You can consider changing C/<CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, at same time.
